runs.text: Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this is a realistic fiction story. It is about a boy from the city who goes on a camping trip in the woods. Discuss the differences between city and country settings.
Then have students point to clues about the setting in the first illustration.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
to hear if she earned a part in the school play.
Ask: What sounds and situations make you feel
Have students whisper-read the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the name of the character who told stories at the campfire. (Mr. Pearson)
What noises does Brady hear? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why does Brady feel anxious about the noises he hears while camping? Explain.
Have you ever had trouble sleeping in a new place? Why?
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this text is a photo comic about the second-person point of view. There are speech bubbles that point to the person who is talking.
Tell students to pay careful attention to both the words and the photos in this text.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
are instructions that explain how to do something or how to get somewhere.
to the post office. The postal worker gives me
on how to mail my package.
Ask: How would you give a new student
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the name of the girl who is looking for a good sandwich. (Sameera)
Which directions should Sameera follow to get to Veras Deli? Find the sentences that answer the question.
How do you know that the recipe is written in the second person? Explain.
What stories or texts have you read that use the second-person point of view?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students read the sentences to a partner. Then have them switch roles.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have students read the sentence to a partner.

Discuss the different end punctuation for sentences 2 (question mark), 3 (period), and 4 (exclamation point). Model how you change your intonation when reading a question (raise voice at end) or exclamation (read with emotion). Then have students read the sentences consecutively.
Read the title. Explain that these are riddles. Each riddle contains clues about a sound. Students must identify what makes the sound.

For the first reading, read the first riddle and have students read the other riddles. Invite volunteers to solve each riddle. Then have students reread the riddles in pairs, alternating lines. Partners can switch lines during the rereadings.
Prompt students to find all words with
spellings in the riddles and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
These supports include the Read/Build/Write routine.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that students will read about kids fears. Point out that each section of text is told from the point of view of a different kid.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
can mean very frightened, or frozen in fear.
Example: Jamal does not ride roller coasters because he is
Ask: How do people act when they are
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word in the title that tells what this text is mostly about. (fear)
What caused Ashley to feel petrified? Find the sentences that answer this question.
How are Danny, Ashley, Jake, and Ana alike? How are they different?
Which of the four fears do you most relate to? Why?
Have students reread the text during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisperread each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
spellings. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
Have them read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss phrasing, or how to chunk longer sentences into meaningful parts. For example, as you read sentence 3, pause briefly after
. Point out that each group of words relates to one idea in the sentence. Have children echo your phrasing.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this text lists common fears that people may have. The author includes a paragraph and a photo for each fear. Have students point to the headings that name the common fears.
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the headings.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when reading each heading and analyzing its related photo.

Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.
Explain to students that they will read a story about how a shoemaker and the elves help each other.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
is to have enough money to buy something.
to buy one video game at the store.
Ask: What is something that people work hard to
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the words that tell what the shoemaker wonders at the beginning of the story. (Who was here?)
What does the shoemaker see when he hides in the shop at night? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Which details from the story show that the shoemaker is generous?
What do you think the shoemaker will buy that he couldnt afford before? Explain.
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this is a story about a girl named Jess who was fearless of most things. Ask students to identify the main character in the photos.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
while using scissors or other sharp objects.
while riding a bicycle or skateboard?
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that Jess uses to describe herself. (fearless)
When does Jess become afraid? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Would Jesss dad agree that it is sometimes good to be cautious? Which details make you think so?
Jess wants to try rock climbing again. Do you think it is a good idea? Explain why or why not.
Have students reread the story during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
